results.title: A Crop of records
results.brief_description: In 1960, Victoria’s wheat growing record was smashed by a bumper harvest. 95% of the wheat was from varieties bred by the Victorian Department of Agriculture including Pinnacle; Insignia; Beacon; and Olympic. Don Rooney, an agronomist in the Wimmera region talks to Victorian farmer Harry Bouchier about his record harvest. We follow the wheat’s journey from the farm, to the silos and finally being loaded onto cargo ships at the Port of Geelong headed for international destinations.

results.title: The Argentine ant
results.brief_description: This film describes the methods used by State and Municipal authorities and C.S.I.R.O. to eradicate the Argentine Ant in large suburban and city areas. The efforts of individual householders to eradicate the pest have proved unsuccessful. The film shows, in detail, the large scale methods developed by the C.S.I.R.O. which have been used systematically and methodically in attempting to eradicate the pest.

results.title: Gaps
results.material_description:
Single channel, High Definition Digital Video.
'Gaps' is a single-channel video with one channel of sound [one stereo pair], which features contemporary dance and occasional dialogue spoken by the performers both as diagetic and voiceover sound. The key to a successful installation is presenting the work in such a way that the content takes precedence over any installation elements. The image should be as large and as clearly visible (i.e. not obscured by columns, other works etc) as is reasonable and comfortable for viewers in proportion to the space, and the audio levels should enable the dialogue to be clearly and easily heard. While projection in a dedicated, sound-locked space is ideal, the work can also be shown on a monitor with headphones. David Rosetzky did mention that this work would not be appropriate for online exhibitions, as it prohibits the viewer from experiencing the work with high quality image and sound.
There is no equipment dedicated or part of this particular work. Equipment should be selected for its ability to display the work at suitable image and sound quality.

Equipment used for ACMI installation (in ACMI's Gallery 2) is listed in the document:
"B2003044_Gaps_CommissionsPreservationQA.docx" linked to this record in the "Documentation" window.
results.brief_description:
One of Australia’s finest video artists, Rosetzky’s captivating works have been exhibited widely throughout Australia and internationally. ‘Gaps’ embodies Rosetzky’s ongoing exploration of personal identity and the relationship - or ‘gaps’ - between self and other through speech, movement and dance.
Rosetzky’s collaborators on ‘Gaps’ include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed ‘How to Feel’ 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.
Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.
The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period. Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.

production_dates.notes:
Co-commissioned by ACMI and Carriageworks (Sydney).
David Rosetzky: Gaps will be a free exhibition at ACMI from 5 August 2014 to 8 February 2015.
The co-commission of Gaps by ACMI and Carriageworks has been assisted by the Australian Government through the Australian Council for the Arts, its arts funding and advisory body.

results.title: Tucker
results.brief_description: Highlights the importance of good food habits. The importance of early experiences is emphasized, together with the valuable role of the school canteen and the teachers who promote good eating habits using the basic five food groups.

results.title: Film work
results.creator_credit: John Hughes and Waterside Workers' Federation of Australia. Film Unit.
results.brief_description: This film recalls the work of the Waterside Workers’ Federation Film Unit. Financed by several trade unions, the Unit produced eleven (mainly documentary) films between 1953-58. There are excerpts from four of the films ‘Pensions for Veterans’, ‘The Hungry Miles’, ‘November Victory’ and ‘Hewers of Coal’ and interviews with the Unit members, Keith Gow, Norma Disher and Jock Levy. (Awards: ATOM 1982)

results.title: Experiments in three colour separation
results.brief_description: A documentary of the work of Arthur and Corinne Cantrill since 1975 in 3-colour separation. Discusses the classic theories and principles in 3-colour separation in film and photography. Commentary by Arthur Cantrill.

results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Collection]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951) was an early aviator and engineer. With the assistance of his brother Reginald Duigan, John built the first Australian-made aircraft to successfully fly, in 1910 at their family’s sheep station, Spring Plains, in Mia Mia, Victoria. Inspired by a postcard sent from a friend in London featuring a photo of Wilbur Wright flying his Model A aeroplane, John successfully built, tested and flew his own biplane and was one of the pioneering aviators in Australia who paved the way for the adventurous pilots of the 1920s. In 1920, John donated his original biplane to the Industrial and Technological Museum in Melbourne (now Museums Victoria). John and Reginald were commemorated as ‘pioneer aviators’ on a 6 cent stamp issued by Australia Post in 1970.

This collection was donated to ACMI by Martin Hudson.

results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, shows a group of film competing in a wheelbarrow race (one person holding another’s ankles while they walk with their hands); running; collecting water in a pail; playing with dogs; rowing on a river or lake; and picnicking and lounging on the grass with 1920s cars behind. The film then shows people on a golfcourse and three women and a dog in the gardens of a large home.

results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, shows an aviation day in a field, with an aeroplane surrounded by spectators and a truck with the word ‘Shell’ parked next to it.

results.title: [John Robertson Duigan Film Collection: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
The John Robertson Duigan Collection is a collection of silent 9.5mm home movies filmed by early aviator and engineer John Robertson Duigan (1882–1951). The collection includes a Pathé-Baby 9.5mm film camera and projector owned by Duigan. The home movies provide an insight into the everyday lives of John and his family in Victoria, including picnics, trips to the Grampians and Colac, family snapshots and aeroplanes of the late 1920s.

This short film, originally shot on 9.5mm film, features a group of people shaking hands, waving and blowing kisses to the camera, followed by a woman and dog in a garden, and possibly Duigan posing with their dog.
